briefOverview: Genealogies from Adam to Enoch frame Enoch’s divine call to preach repentance and a revealed exposition of the fall, baptism, and the plan of salvation.
summary: Adam’s posterity through Seth keep a pure language, records, and priesthood, yet violence and secret works spread across the earth. God calls Enoch, empowering him with protection and seeric vision, to warn a hard-hearted people and summon them to repent and serve the Creator. Enoch testifies of creation, the fall, and pervasive satanic deception, declaring that God commanded all to repent and be baptized in the name of the Only Begotten, Jesus Christ, who would come in the meridian of time. The Lord explains that original guilt is atoned for, that humans possess agency, and that parents must teach their children repentance and holiness. Salvation requires being born again of water and the Spirit, and sanctified by the blood of the Only Begotten; all things in creation bear record of God. Adam himself is baptized, receives the Holy Ghost and priesthood identity, and is declared a son of God.
externalContext: The Book of Moses is part of the Latter-day Saint Pearl of Great Price, presenting material associated with Joseph Smith’s early nineteenth-century revision of Genesis. Its genealogical listing parallels the antediluvian lines of Genesis 5, where extraordinarily long lifespans are a literary feature of ancient Near Eastern primeval history. Enoch, briefly mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, became a prominent figure in Second Temple Jewish literature (e.g., 1 Enoch) as a visionary and preacher. The chapter’s language about priesthood, baptism, and the “meridian of time” reflects broader Christian theological vocabulary as understood in Latter-day Saint tradition.
externalReferences: This chapter parallels and expands Genesis 4:25–5:29, especially the Enoch notices in Genesis 5:22–24, while Jude 1:14–15 also portrays Enoch prophesying judgment. The description of an order “without beginning of days or end of years” echoes Hebrews 7:3’s depiction of Melchizedek. The teaching on being “born of water and of the Spirit” and “baptized with fire and the Holy Ghost” resonates with John 3:5 and Matthew 3:11. Its treatment of Adam’s fall and death’s universality aligns with Romans 5:12–19 and 1 Corinthians 15:22, and the insistence that nothing unclean dwells with God parallels Revelation 21:27.
practicalQuestions: What practices today might parallel the chapter’s “book of remembrance” to help families remember and keep God’s covenants?
How do we respond to feelings of inadequacy, like Enoch’s, when called to speak or serve?
In what concrete ways can we “teach these things freely” to our children or communities?
How might we more intentionally experience being “born again” of water and the Spirit, not just ritually but inwardly?
Where do we see “all things” bearing record of God in our daily environment, and how can that awareness shape our choices?
uncertainAreas: The nature and scope of the “language of Adam” and the mechanics of record-keeping are not detailed. The extraordinary lifespans, place names (e.g., Shulon, Cainan), and movements of peoples are sparse in geographical and chronological specificity. The exact referent of the “order…without beginning of days or end of years” is implied but not explicitly named. The statement that children are “conceived in sin” alongside the claim that original guilt is atoned for invites nuanced interpretation of inherited vs. personal sin within the text’s framework.
